Problem:
class Experiment { int temp; double reactionRate; void increaseTemp() { temp += 5; if (temp > 100) reactionRate *= 2; else reactionRate += 10; } void decreaseReaction() { if (reactionRate > 20) { reactionRate -= 5; temp -= 3; } } }",

If an external method sets the temperature exactly to 105, will the reaction rate double?
Explanation: Setting the temperature to 105 explicitly meets the condition in the 'increaseTemp()' method where the temperature exceeding 100 leads to the reaction rate being doubled. As this is a direct condition in the code, intervening to set the temperature to 105 will result in doubling the reaction rate as per the logic defined.

List only distinct and meaningful causal relations. Do not provide any final answer to the question. Focus only on extracting the causal structure. Output strictly in JSON format: {"causal_relation": "A → B; C → D; ..."}.
causal_map: temp → reactionRate; increaseTemp → temp; increaseTemp → reactionRate; reactionRate → reactionRate (feedback loop); temp → increaseTemp; increaseTemp → decreaseReaction; reactionRate → decreaseReaction
